Authors:
Youngju Min, Myung Soo Park, Jonathan J. Fong, Ying Quan,
Sungcheol Jung, Young Woon Lim
Title:
Diversity of Endophytic Fungi associated with Pinus
thunbergii in coastal shelterbelts of Korea
Keywords:
Diversity, Endophytic fungi, Pinus thunbergii, Salinity
tolerance, Shelterbelt
Abstract:
In Korea, the Black pine, Pinus thunbergii, is widely
distributed on the eastern coast and was highlighted for its importance
as a shelterbelt after the 2011 Japanese tsunami. We investigate the
saline resistance of P. thunbergii root endophytes in relation to site
(Goseong, Uljin, Busan) and location (inland, shoreline) using culturing
and molecular methods. Endophytic fungi were isolated from root tips of
P. thunbergii and growth rates of pure cultured isolates were measured
and compared between PDA with and without 3% NaCl to confirm their
saline resistance. A total of 259 endophytic fungi were isolated and
organized into 136 morphotypes. DNA sequencing of the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS) identified 58 species among the morphotypes.
Representatives of three fungal phyla were present: 44 Ascomycota, 8
Zygomycota, and 6 Basidiomycota. Penicillium spp. and Trichoderma spp.
were the dominant endophytic fungi, and many grew well in saline media.
We find five endophyte species common to all sites, with three being
saline resistant. No statistical difference in endophyte communities
between sites or location was found. However, more saline resistant
species associated with Busan and with shoreline environments. Analyzing
soil properties, Busan had higher salt and nitrogen levels that were
statistically significant. These soil differences may influence the
number of saline resistant endophytes present at a site. This
investigation indicates that many endophytic fungi of P. thunbergii
possess the ability to proliferate in saline soil and potentially play a
role in growth and regeneration of coastal P. thunbergii.
